qas.question: Which interpretation of Avicenna's work was more taught in Islamic schools?
Interpretations of Avicenna's work split into how many different schools?
Who used only parts of Avicenna's works to support their own great spiritual insights?
Who used Avicenna's work to help understand future political events?
What are Islamic schools also known as?
Who's philosophy was spilt into 4 different schools?
Which interpretation of Avicenna's work was banned in Islamic schools?
What did al-Tusi believe Avicenna's theological works were isolated from?
Who's philosophy did Avicenna use to gain greater spiritual insight?
Which interpretation of Avicenna's work was less taught in Islamic schools?
Misinterpretations of Avicenna's work split into how many different schools?
Who used only parts of Avicenna's works to reject their own great spiritual insights?
Who used Avicenna's work to help understand past political events?
What are Islamic schools not known as?

context: Later interpretations of <b5_0>Avicenna's<b5_0/> philosophy split into <a1_0><b10_0>three<b10_0/><a1_0/> different schools; those (such as <a3_0><b12_0>al-Tusi<b12_0/><a3_0/>) who continued to apply his philosophy as a system to interpret later political events and scientific advances; those (such as <b6_0><b9_0>al-Razi<b9_0/>)<b6_0/> who considered Avicenna's theological works in isolation from <b7_0>his wider philosophical concerns<b7_0/>; and those (such as <a2_0><b8_0><b11_0>al-Ghazali<b11_0/><b8_0/><a2_0/>) who selectively used parts of his philosophy to support their own attempts to gain greater spiritual insights through a variety of mystical means. It was the theological interpretation championed by those such as <a0_0>al-Razi<a0_0/> which eventually came to predominate in the <a4_0><b13_0>madrasahs<b13_0/><a4_0/>.
